content:
So I don't have much time and I only got to work on this equation with z3 since the middle of this week. This list isn't complete even with what I have now. So far I have some rather trivial insights:

  1. Firstly I chose z3 because it had an easily accessible python API. I believe it is not too hard to adapt this to cvc5 since that one has a nearly identical python API.
  2. I have conducted most of my runs on Ints as the canonical infinite domain.
  3. A few trivial things that I think are already known or easily visible by a quick glance at the equations: the binary operation of the Magma refuting the implication has to be : non-associative, non-commutative, non-idempotent. Further it cannot have a left identity.
  4. I have a conjecture based on experiments that restricting the range of values of xxx or yyy from above and below, within which they can deviate from the projection operations does not yield a counterexample. EDIT : z3 confirms this.

I will add more in the next few days to the above. In addition, and to a smaller extent, I have basically been trying to apply the methods of 1323 to this and none of the methods have yielded a counterexample so far. That being said, my goal there was to replicate the methods, and it was easiest to do so on finite examples and we don't expect finite counterexamples for this one.
The reason I checked the last point is the way z3 was presenting its models of functions: A tabulation of values for small integers and a projection function for all other values.

Point 4 above and some basic runs on z3 suggest to me that Integers (although SMT solvers have a great theory for them usually) are poor candidates for finding a counterexample. For instance, a few days ago z3 and cvc5 had a lot of trouble trying to find an operation satisfying 1729 (which is trivially satisfied by subtraction) without extra hints.

Lastly, apologies for not getting to this earlier. I have been under extreme time constraints. Also, if any of this gets double posted, I am sorry about that too. Zulip's android app gives me a lot of trouble in this department

Thanks for the update! I am suspecting that if one is to try to import the latest 1323-solving technology to 1729, one will need a good "base model" for 1729 on the squares, which would not directly refute 817, but could then be extended to non-squares. Looking forward to the full update!

Perhaps in the meantime, the following prepatory questions could be answered through ATPs, in analogy with how they laid the groundwork for the 1323 solution:

  1. Is it safe to assume that the 1729 model is unital? Does this lead to simpler formulations of the 1729 law?
  2. Is it safe to assume that the set SMSMSM of squares is closed under multiplication?
  3. Is it ruled out that the squares could be constant? What if the squares take only two values +1,−1+1,-1+1,−1?

A small extension to the update : In my pen and paper work I wanted to find a natural way to create non-associative operations from simple ones. I came up with a "stateful operations" heuristic to do this. The idea comes to me from basic ML theory, where a larger hypothesis space is defined by parametrising over a smaller hypothesis space. (EDIT: In hindsight, it seems this can also be motivated by concurrency race conditions). The point is to have a bit more parametric control over the binary operation with the hope that SMT solvers have less trouble performing a parameter search than an uninterpreted function search for the full binary operation. All this is still a bit hazy and I want to run this on z3 and cvc5.

To give a trivial but illustrative example of this statefulness: Suppose the underlying domain is Int×BitInt \times BitInt×Bit. Suppose (x,s1)⋄(y,s2)(x, s_1) \diamond (y,s_2)(x,s1​)⋄(y,s2​) is defined as (x∘y,s1⊕s2⊕1)(x \circ y, s_1 \oplus s_2\oplus 1) (x∘y,s1​⊕s2​⊕1) where ∘=+\circ = +∘=+ when s1⊕s2=0s_1 \oplus s_2 = 0s1​⊕s2​=0 and ∘=−\circ = - ∘=− otherwise. Then (x,0)⋄((y,0)⋄(z,0))=(x−y−z,0)(x, 0) \diamond ((y, 0) \diamond (z,0)) = (x - y - z, 0) (x,0)⋄((y,0)⋄(z,0))=(x−y−z,0) whereas ((x,0)⋄(y,0))⋄(z,0)((x,0) \diamond (y,0)) \diamond (z,0)((x,0)⋄(y,0))⋄(z,0) will be (x+y−z,0)(x + y -z, 0)(x+y−z,0). The intuition here is that the state BitBitBit tracks the parity of number of operation uses and the use of non-associative operations in some cases ensures that the order of application of the individual instances ⋄\diamond⋄ makes a difference.

Terence Tao said:

Thanks for the update! I am suspecting that if one is to try to import the latest 1323-solving technology to 1729, one will need a good "base model" for 1729 on the squares, which would not directly refute 817, but could then be extended to non-squares. Looking forward to the full update!

Perhaps in the meantime, the following prepatory questions could be answered through ATPs, in analogy with how they laid the groundwork for the 1323 solution:

  1. Is it safe to assume that the 1729 model is unital? Does this lead to simpler formulations of the 1729 law?
  2. Is it safe to assume that the set SMSMSM of squares is closed under multiplication?
  3. Is it ruled out that the squares could be constant? What if the squares take only two values +1,−1+1,-1+1,−1?

This sounds like a good starting point. I'll try these out

This seems to align with some of the strategies we've tried successfully for other equations in which we assume there is a homomorphism from the desired magma to some small base magma (such as BitBitBit) which often seems to clarify the algebra and enforce some good structural properties.

Right, so I am approaching this from the point of view "What natural operations in computer science would not have the usual algebraic properties". It is trivial to find non-commutative operations (any monad would do). But non-associativity is much harder, since almost every nice data structure I can think of in CS has some sequential composition notion which corresponds to associativity. Things change when one adds statefulness
and then the challenge is to start with basic non-associative operations and build more complex ones, and parametric ones.
I think I ruled out the squares being +/-1 already, but I'll add an experiment to my notebook again to confirm this.

Terence Tao said:

  1. Is it safe to assume that the 1729 model is unital? Does this lead to simpler formulations of the 1729 law?

Since I haven't been in a math dept for a while, I am guessing by unital you mean it has an identity element with left and right identity laws. The left identity law is ruled out. Having a right identity hasn't yielded much so far.
basically 1729 is not consistent with a left identity rule

Another observation, for the fallback conditions, when beyond a certain range of values of $x$, I implement subtraction as a fall back rule, even for large limits I get unsatisfiability. But when I turn the limit into a variable z3 can't find it. This wasn't the case when the fallback rules were projections
The right identity law is also inconsistent with 1729
OK, so imposing units is a bust. Good to know!
I take that last one back. right identity is not confirmed yet. I had a minor error

Another possible simplifying assumption is S2=SS^2 = SS2=S, i.e., squares are idempotent (equation 151), or S2=0S^2 = 0S2=0 for some constant 000 (which will necessarily equal the right identity, if it exists).
I already tried idempotence. I am currently on my machine and setting up everything in my notebook but not running any solver longer than 2 minutes.
So far all the indeterminate runs have been run under 2 minutes.
S2=eS^2 = eS2=e is ruled out for any constant eee
Based on my experience so far, positive constraints narrow down the search much more quickly than negative constraints.
at least positive equational constraints. This intuitively makes sense.

Perhaps the most important remaining constraint to test is whether SMSMSM can be closed: the product of two squares is always a square. This seems rather key if one is to try a "build the multiplication table on the squares first" approach.
Running it. I'll report back in a few hours.

Right identity is ruled out (assuming you are looking for a counterexample) since in equation 1729, x=(yy)((yx)y)x = (yy)((yx)y)x=(yy)((yx)y), if 1 is a right identity, then substituting x=1 gives 1=(yy)(yy)1 = (yy)(yy)1=(yy)(yy). Then equation 817 x=x((xx)(xx))x = x((xx)(xx))x=x((xx)(xx)) becomes x=x1x = x1x=x1 which is true.
That's my idea too but I want to coax z3 to say so
In my earlier attempt I had forgotten to remove a different constraint which gave unsat
Further attempts on left identity have shown too much variance in running times.
And z3 didn't terminate the right identity for a long while
Vampire finds the proof for right identity instantly.
Interesting. What's the ground theory you are using?
Does vampire have some inbuilt support for equational reasoning that smt solvers don't?
I'm not familiar with internals of Vampire but I believe it does have support for equational reasoning, based on the proof it outputs.
The proof from Vampire is basically the same as the one I wrote above.
Does vampire have an easy API in other languages
So far I haven't seen anything in that direction. I will also try cvc5
It doesn't seem to have an API for other languages, only its own CLI interface
Oh that's sad. I was hoping I could just plug it into a jupyter notebook. So far with z3 and a bit of cvc5, it has been very useful

I suspect the 3-step procedure used to resolve 1516->255 has a good chance of working for 1729->817. The steps are:

  1. First build a 1516 model SMSMSM for the squares, with some additional properties TBD (analogous to the "double surjectivity" in the 1516 case) required to advance to step 2. In particular, the SM×SMSM \times SMSM×SM block of the multiplication table is now filled in: we understand "squares x squares".
  2. Work out the SM×(M\SM)SM \times (M \backslash SM)SM×(M\SM) and (M\SM)×M(M \backslash SM) \times M(M\SM)×M blocks of the table ("squares x non-squares" and "non-squares x squares"). Here I think we mostly rely on the form LSaRaLa=1L_{Sa} R_a L_a = 1LSa​Ra​La​=1 of the 1729 law for a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM. For squares, all the left and right multiplication operators are invertible, so for instance Ra=LSa−1La−1R_a = L_{Sa}^{-1} L_a^{-1}Ra​=LSa−1​La−1​, which tells us that the "non-squares x squares" block of the table is determined by the "squares x non-squares" block. Some additional properties (analogous to the "infinite surjectivity" in the 1516 case) need to be imposed to advance to step 3.
  3. Fill in the last block (M\SM)×(M\SM)(M \backslash SM) \times (M \backslash SM)(M\SM)×(M\SM) of the multiplication table. This should be relatively straightforward because 1729 now reduces to a law of the form (y⋄x)⋄y=known(y \diamond x) \diamond y = \hbox{known}(y⋄x)⋄y=known which looks easy to fill in greedily, assuming that we have had the foresight to implement some suitable "infinite surjectivity" type hypothesis in step 2.

Ted Hwa said:

Right identity is ruled out (assuming you are looking for a counterexample) since in equation 1729, x=(yy)((yx)y)x = (yy)((yx)y)x=(yy)((yx)y), if 1 is a right identity, then substituting x=1 gives 1=(yy)(yy)1 = (yy)(yy)1=(yy)(yy). Then equation 817 x=x((xx)(xx))x = x((xx)(xx))x=x((xx)(xx)) becomes x=x1x = x1x=x1 which is true.

Btw, to put it out there, this argument is important in my argument for left identity being inconsistent with 1729, since if there was a left identity, 1L1_L1L​, using y=1Ly= 1_Ly=1L​ in 1729, it reduces to x=x⋄1Lx = x \diamond 1_Lx=x⋄1L​ for every xxx. Now this makes 1L1_L1L​ a right identity.
Which in turn is inconsistent with negating 817
One thing I must note is that z3 has been behind my mental math in almost all observations. The exception is the refutation of some fallback based operations.

Terence Tao said:

I suspect the 3-step procedure used to resolve 1516->255 has a good chance of working for 1729->817. The steps are:

  1. First build a 1516 model SMSMSM for the squares, with some additional properties TBD (analogous to the "double surjectivity" in the 1516 case) required to advance to step 2. In particular, the SM×SMSM \times SMSM×SM block of the multiplication table is now filled in: we understand "squares x squares".
  2. Work out the SM×(M\SM)SM \times (M \backslash SM)SM×(M\SM) and (M\SM)×M(M \backslash SM) \times M(M\SM)×M blocks of the table ("squares x non-squares" and "non-squares x squares"). Here I think we mostly rely on the form LSaRaLa=1L_{Sa} R_a L_a = 1LSa​Ra​La​=1 of the 1729 law for a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM. For squares, all the left and right multiplication operators are invertible, so for instance Ra=LSa−1La−1R_a = L_{Sa}^{-1} L_a^{-1}Ra​=LSa−1​La−1​, which tells us that the "non-squares x squares" block of the table is determined by the "squares x non-squares" block. Some additional properties (analogous to the "infinite surjectivity" in the 1516 case) need to be imposed to advance to step 3.
  3. Fill in the last block (M\SM)×(M\SM)(M \backslash SM) \times (M \backslash SM)(M\SM)×(M\SM) of the multiplication table. This should be relatively straightforward because 1729 now reduces to a law of the form (y⋄x)⋄y=known(y \diamond x) \diamond y = \hbox{known}(y⋄x)⋄y=known which looks easy to fill in greedily, assuming that we have had the foresight to implement some suitable "infinite surjectivity" type hypothesis in step 2.

Sounds like a plan, although I should probably do this tomorrow. It is rather late now in my part of the world.
It is possible I need to tweak/improve my way of using these SMT solvers, as the same heuristics don't seem to translate one-one to other ATPs

I have been doing some not yet successful pen and paper work building off my "stateful operation" heuristic. At first glance this heuristic appears to allow us to have heterogeneous operations whose effect depends on the position of the operator's occurrence in the abstract syntax tree (AST) of an expression. For instance if one looks at the height of the operators in equations 817 and 1729. Let's use subtraction as our basic operation. Looking at the ASTs of 817 and 1729, it is clear that if we apply flipped subtraction (x⋄y=y−x x \diamond y = y -x x⋄y=y−x) at height 3 nodes, we can break 817 and we can fix this breakage in 1729 by using flipped subtraction in height 1 nodes. For height 0 nodes we use normal subtraction.

However this is not enough. We homogenise these heterogeneous operations by encoding some extra data in the operands (for example by adding a height modulo 3 parameter to the domain) that carries some info about the . The operation itself needs to be defined uniformly on inputs regardless of the input height parameter. In particular 1729 must be satisfied independent of the height parameter component of the input arguments to the parameters xxx and yyy. nFor example a user might give an equation in which 1729's rhs is a subterm whose root occurs at height 5. It might receive as input values with varying heights. The goal is to get a better operation that is uniform w.r.t. input "heights"
Maybe height of the operand node is the wrong parameter to focus on, although it seems easiest.

Terence Tao ha dicho:

  1. Is it ruled out that the squares could be constant? What if the squares take only two values +1,−1?

Only two squares is quickly ruled out by Vampire-SAT (as expected, Prover9 is still running on it after 8 minutes...).

@Shreyas Srinivas does it look like your stateful operation constructions could at least produce interesting infinite models of 1729 even if they cannot fulfill 817? They may be useful recipes for step 1 of the three-step procedure I mentioned previously.

If we wanted to pursue the 3-step strategy more, I think the first thing to do is focus on step 3: assuming that the multiplication table is already filled in SM×M∪M×SMSM \times M \cup M \times SMSM×M∪M×SM, what axioms need to be satisfied on that portion of the table in order to be able to easily fill in the non-square portion (M\SM)×(M\SM)(M \backslash SM) \times (M \backslash SM)(M\SM)×(M\SM) by a greedy algorithm? Note that 817 doesn't directly care about this portion, as it can be tested purely using the M×SMM \times SMM×SM component, so if we can get a clean criterion for solvability of the completion problem of the multiplication table from SM×M∪M×SMSM \times M \cup M \times SMSM×M∪M×SM to M×MM \times MM×M, then this should resolve Step 3 and leave us just with working out the other two steps.
With my model refuting 817 is easy. It is satisfying 1729 that is more difficult
Because whatever extra parameters I tack on to integers, 1729 must be satisfied for all possible instantiations

Basically the only structurally asymmetric occurrence of the operator in 817 is the first instance from the left (or the root of the AST). The modification of this occurence must be compensated for in 1729. In my example above, when using subtraction as a building block, this means flipping the height 2 occurrences
But satisfying 1729 by itself without worrying about 817 is easy
Subtraction satisfies it
It's just not super useful

Jose Brox said:

Terence Tao ha dicho:

  1. Is it ruled out that the squares could be constant? What if the squares take only two values +1,−1?

Only two squares is quickly ruled out by Vampire-SAT (as expected, Prover9 is still running on it after 8 minutes...).

I am really curious as to why vampire seems to be so much more successful than basically any other prover (including in several cases, just pen and paper work).

Are you able to construct a model of 1729 in which the iterated squaring map S3S^3S3 is non-constant, where Sx=x⋄xSx = x \diamond xSx=x⋄x (so S3x=((x⋄x)⋄(x⋄x))⋄((x⋄x)⋄(x⋄x))S^3 x = ((x \diamond x) \diamond (x \diamond x)) \diamond ((x \diamond x) \diamond (x \diamond x))S3x=((x⋄x)⋄(x⋄x))⋄((x⋄x)⋄(x⋄x)))? I have an idea on how to make the 3-step program work, but it requires a seed model in which S3S^3S3 is non-constant (more precisely I need the set {S2x,S3x}\{ S^2 x, S^3 x\}{S2x,S3x} to vary in a non-trivial way in xxx, but presumably making S3S^3S3 non-constant will do this).
Not yet, but I think there might be a way to do that on pen and paper. Intuitively, I just need to keep track of the number of continuous applications of an element to itself
And reset the counter on non-contiguous occurrences, and also an extra state variable to keep track of the last value assigned to a cube
Also keep the starting values of the counters in memory for reference. At this point I am just defining a Moore machine
Sorry a mealy machine and then convert it to a moore machine.
And then encode its table in an operator.
I'll get on with this and report back in a few hours

Actually I think I may just need a model with S2S^2S2 non-constant (not S3S^3S3).

The model I have in mind is that of an infinite submagma SMSMSM of squares (in which S2S^2S2 is non-constant, so S3S^3S3 will be non-constant in the entire magma), and then a larger set M\SM=SM×(F2SM)0M \backslash SM = SM \times ({\mathbf F}_2^{SM})_0M\SM=SM×(F2SM​)0​ of non-squares (a,x)(a,x)(a,x), where a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM and xxx is in the free abelian group (F2SM)0({\mathbf F}_2^{SM})_0(F2SM​)0​ of exponent 2 generated by a generator ebe_beb​ of order 2 for each b∈SMb \in SMb∈SM. The squaring map on non-squares is to be given by S(a,x)=aS(a,x) = aS(a,x)=a, and the left-multiplication by squares b∈SMb \in SMb∈SM given by
Lb(a,x)=(a,x+eb). L_b (a,x) = (a, x + e_b).Lb​(a,x)=(a,x+eb​).
These operators commute and are involutions, so the Ramanujan law LSbRbLb=IL_{Sb} R_b L_b = ILSb​Rb​Lb​=I then tells us what the right-multiplication by squares given by
Rb(a,x)=(a,x+eb+eSb). R_b (a,x) = (a, x + e_b + e_{Sb}).Rb​(a,x)=(a,x+eb​+eSb​).
If the squaring map is non-trivial enough, one should have Rb(a,x)R_b(a,x)Rb​(a,x) take different values as bbb varies. To get a 817 violation we need something like S3S^3S3 being non-trivial globally, so S2S^2S2 should be non-trivial on the submagma SMSMSM.

To fill out the remainder of the multiplication table for non-squares, there is a constraint Rb(a,x)⋄(a,x)=La−1bR_b (a,x) \diamond (a,x) = L_a^{-1} bRb​(a,x)⋄(a,x)=La−1​b, and 1729 for non-squares basically reduces to the law
(a,x)⋄(b,y)=(c,z)  ⟹  (c,z)⋄(a,x)=(b,y+ea). (a,x) \diamond (b,y) = (c,z) \implies (c,z) \diamond (a,x) = (b, y + e_a).(a,x)⋄(b,y)=(c,z)⟹(c,z)⋄(a,x)=(b,y+ea​).
This law iterates to produce 6-cycles similar to the 1323 construction, so I think there is a good chance of filling out the table by a greedy construction.

I will need a bit more time. But I have had many false starts on the domain Int×{0,1,2}Int \times \{0,1,2\}Int×{0,1,2} where the latter set has the usual order but increment and decrement, and consequently addition and subtraction wrap around (basically all operations on the second element are modulo 3). Intuitively, when the absolute value of height difference (denoted by 0,1,2). The base operation is subtraction of reals. To satisfy 1729, one must encoded that if the height difference on the left and right are 0 then apply normal subtraction whereas when they are not, apply flipped subtraction.

An alternative is that at 0 height difference apply flipped subtraction, at height diff 1, apply addition, and at height difference 2 apply normal subtraction. This can get a non constant square operation. The challenge is to figure out the correct formulation for the new height of the result of the operation. This has been my last few hours of work. At times it has taken me tantalising close to an answer only for me to find out that for each height assignment I have constructed so far, EQ 1729 breaks at some place or the other

Breaking 817 is easy. So far I have been exploiting the only asymmetry in 817 which is the height 2 occurrence of ⋄\diamond⋄, and I am using it as a guideline for constructing the conditional statement for switching operations.
I am a bit tied up for the next 3 days. I'll post an update on Sunday. Hopefully I have a way to safely handle bad state inputs by then
In the meantime, when I have a half an hour here or there to spare, I will try to post some of the simple examples as lean code here, so that others can modify and play with the idea.

If constructing a base model is too hard, it may be possible to pull off a "swindle" and perform an infinite number of extensions to get a non-trivial model, without ever having to verify the base model properties at all, by pushing the base model further and further back in "time" and passing to the limit. I haven't really thought this idea through, but I guess we'll see first how the efforts to build non-trivial 1729 models are going.
Did the recent correction to the argument for 1323 impact the idea to build a 1729 -> 817 counterexample from a model with S2S^2S2 non-constant?

I think 817 has a different flavor to 2744, it only needs the "non-squares x squares" portion of the multiplication table rather than the "non-squares x non-squares" to refute. But I haven't worked out any details yet.

Here is a negative result: if one has S(x⋄S2x)=SxS( x \diamond S^2 x ) = S xS(x⋄S2x)=Sx, then 817 holds. So this actually rules out the type of models used for 1323, as they obey this rule (at least for non-squares, in fact the model obeys the stronger law S(x⋄Sy)=S(Sy⋄x)=SxS(x \diamond Sy) = S(Sy \diamond x) = SxS(x⋄Sy)=S(Sy⋄x)=Sx for non-square xxx); we need to find a more complex model that avoids this rule.

Proof: 1729 states that LSyRyLyx=xL_{Sy} R_{y} L_y x = xLSy​Ry​Ly​x=x. Setting y=xy=xy=x we obtain LSx2x=xL_{Sx}^2 x = xLSx2​x=x. Next, replacing x,yx,yx,y by S2x,xS^2x, xS2x,x we have LSx(RS2xx⋄x)=S2xL_{Sx} (R_{S^2 x} x \diamond x) = S^2 xLSx​(RS2x​x⋄x)=S2x, so RS2xx⋄x=SxR_{S^2 x} x \diamond x = SxRS2x​x⋄x=Sx by invertibility of LSxL_{Sx}LSx​. Replacing x,yx,yx,y by x,RS2xxx, R_{S^2 x} xx,RS2x​x and using the hypothesis we have LSxRRS2xxSx=xL_{Sx} R_{R_{S^2 x} x} Sx = xLSx​RRS2x​x​Sx=x, hence LSx2RS2xx=x=LSx2xL_{Sx}^2 R_{S^2 x} x = x = L_{Sx}^2 xLSx2​RS2x​x=x=LSx2​x. By invertibility of LSxL_{Sx}LSx​ we conclude RS2xx=xR_{S^2 x} x = xRS2x​x=x, but this is 817. □\Box□

Conversely, 817, which is x⋄S2x=xx \diamond S^2 x = xx⋄S2x=x, clearly implies S(x⋄S2x)=SxS( x \diamond S^2 x ) = S xS(x⋄S2x)=Sx. So it is really the law S(x⋄S2x)=SxS( x \diamond S^2 x ) = S xS(x⋄S2x)=Sx that needs to be refuted, rather than x⋄S2x=xx \diamond S^2 x = xx⋄S2x=x.

It may be useful to repeat the ATP-assisted exercise we have done in similar equations of trying to find additional axioms we can place on top of 1729 that can simplify the algebra without accidentally proving 817. So for instance S(x⋄S2x)=SxS(x \diamond S^2x) = SxS(x⋄S2x)=Sx would be an example of an axiom that we cannot impose; the laws SLSyx=SxS L_{Sy} x = SxSLSy​x=Sx and SRSyx=SxS R_{Sy} x = SxSRSy​x=Sx similarly cannot be imposed (the former implies the latter since RSy=LS2y−1LSy−1R_{Sy} = L_{S^2y}^{-1} L_{Sy}^{-1}RSy​=LS2y−1​LSy−1​).
Another observation: the identity RS2xx⋄x=SxR_{S^2 x} x \diamond x = SxRS2x​x⋄x=Sx just proven shows that the law 817 holds whenever RxR_xRx​ is injective, in particular 817 holds for squares.
I will have time to do this tomorrow. I'll try to run multiple ATPs

Thanks! Some sample questions that ATPs may be able to answer (with partial confidence):

  • Can we assume that squares are closed under multiplication, i.e., that for all x,yx,yx,y there exists zzz such that Sx⋄Sy=SzSx \diamond Sy = SzSx⋄Sy=Sz?
  • Can we assume there a right unit x⋄0=xx \diamond 0 = xx⋄0=x? What about a left unit 0⋄x=x0 \diamond x = x0⋄x=x (which I think is stronger)?
  • Can we assume S2S^2S2 is a constant? (Probably not.) What about S3S^3S3? Or maybe S2=SS^2 = SS2=S or S3=S2S^3 = S^2S3=S2 could be viable axioms.
  • Could left-multiplication by squares be abelian, thus Sx⋄(Sy⋄z)=Sy⋄(Sx⋄z)Sx \diamond (Sy \diamond z) = Sy \diamond (Sx \diamond z)Sx⋄(Sy⋄z)=Sy⋄(Sx⋄z)? This would also imply that right multiplication on squares is abelian. Separately, could we assume that left-multiplication by squares is an involution, Sx⋄(Sx⋄y)=ySx \diamond (Sx \diamond y) = ySx⋄(Sx⋄y)=y?

Infinitesimal update: many z3 runs ongoing. I think I already ruled out S2S^2S2 being constant because in 817, S2(x)S^2(x)S2(x) would become an identity element, and our elusive counterexample can have neither left nor right identity
Further, higher up in the thread we already have proofs that we can't have a right or left identity (one follows from the other)

Just reporting what would be needed to extend a base 1729 magma SMSMSM (representing "squares") to a larger magma M=SM⊎NM = SM \uplus NM=SM⊎N (with NNN representing "nonsquares"), thus we are restricting attention to models where the set of squares SMSMSM is closed under multiplication, and is already given to us somehow.

I will consistently use a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c for elements of SMSMSM and x,y,zx,y,zx,y,z for elements of NNN (or MMM). This requires introducing a squaring map S:N→SMS: N \to SMS:N→SM and to complete the original mutiplication table ⋄:SM×SM→SM\diamond: SM \times SM \to SM⋄:SM×SM→SM to MMM. From the bijective nature of La,RaL_a, R_aLa​,Ra​ for a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM we know that these maps have to permute the non-squares, thus we have to define bijections La,Ra:N→NL_a, R_a: N \to NLa​,Ra​:N→N as well as the multiplication operation ⋄:N×N→M\diamond: N \times N \to M⋄:N×N→M for non-squares.

1729 asserts that LSyRyLy=1L_{Sy} R_y L_y = 1LSy​Ry​Ly​=1. For squares a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM, we can rearrange this as

Ra=LSa−1La−1(1). R_a = L_{Sa}^{-1} L_a^{-1}\quad (1).Ra​=LSa−1​La−1​(1).

Thus the right-multiplication operators Ra:N→NR_a: N \to NRa​:N→N, a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM are completely determined by the left-multiplication operators La:N→NL_a: N \to NLa​:N→N, a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM.

Applying 1729 with y∈Ny \in Ny∈N and a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM, we obtain LSyRyLya=aL_{Sy} R_y L_y a = aLSy​Ry​Ly​a=a, which we can rearrange as
Ray⋄y=LSy−1a(2). R_a y \diamond y = L_{Sy}^{-1} a \quad (2).Ra​y⋄y=LSy−1​a(2).
This fills out part of the multiplication table on N×NN \times NN×N. One has to ensure that this rule does not collide with itself, or with the consistency condition
y⋄y=Sy(3) y \diamond y= Sy \quad (3)y⋄y=Sy(3)
so we need the RayR_a yRa​y to be distinct from each other and from yyy as a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM varies (an exception can be made if a=S2ya = S^2 ya=S2y, but we do not want to make this exception for all yyy as this would precisely give 817).

1729 can also be written as
y⋄x=z  ⟹  z⋄y=LSy−1x. y \diamond x = z \implies z \diamond y = L_{Sy}^{-1} x.y⋄x=z⟹z⋄y=LSy−1​x.
Applying this with (3) and y∈Ny \in Ny∈N we obtain the constraint
LSy2y=y(4) L_{Sy}^2 y = y \quad (4)LSy2​y=y(4)
so yyy is either a fixed point or a 2-periodic point of the permutation LSy:N→NL_{Sy}: N \to NLSy​:N→N. Applying this instead with (2),we obtain
LLSy−1aRay=LSRay−1y L_{L_{Sy}^{-1} a} R_a y = L_{SR_a y}^{-1} yLLSy−1​a​Ra​y=LSRa​y−1​y
for y∈Ny \in Ny∈N and a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM. We can change variables a bit and write this constraint as
LSRSy⋄ayLaRSy⋄ay=y(5). L_{SR_{Sy \diamond a} y} L_a R_{Sy \diamond a} y = y \quad (5).LSRSy⋄a​y​La​RSy⋄a​y=y(5).
It was tempting to simplify this law by asking that right-multiplication did not affect squares, so that SRSy⋄ay=SySR_{Sy \diamond a} y = SySRSy⋄a​y=Sy. But then (5) and (4), together with the invertibility of LSyL_{Sy}LSy​, would simplify to
LaRSy⋄ay=LSyy L_a R_{Sy \diamond a} y = L_{Sy} yLa​RSy⋄a​y=LSy​y
and setting a=Sya = Sya=Sy we would obtain
RS2yy=y(817)R_{S^2 y} y = y \quad (817)RS2y​y=y(817)
which is 817. So we need right-multiplication to affect squares at least once .

Anyway, I believe (1), (4), (5) are the main constraints. If we can find a base 1729 magma SMSMSM and left and right multiplication operators La,Ra:N→NL_a, R_a: N \to NLa​,Ra​:N→N for a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM obeying (1), (4), (5) but not (817), and with the RayR_a yRa​y distinct from each other and from yyy as aaa varies, then we should be able to greedily fill in the rest of the table (providing NNN is infinite and nothing too bad happens with the iteration).

For the record, we have the following non-trivial model of 1729, which unfortunately obeys 817, but could potentially be a base model for a larger 1729 magma that violates 817.

Let GGG be a countably infinite abelian group of exponent 2. The carrier is G×GG \times GG×G. The multiplication law is partially given by
(x,a)⋄(b,0)=(b,0)⋄(x,a)=(x+b,a)(x,a) \diamond (b,0) = (b,0) \diamond (x,a) = (x+b, a)(x,a)⋄(b,0)=(b,0)⋄(x,a)=(x+b,a)
(x,a)⋄(x+b,a)=(a+b,0).(x,a) \diamond (x+b,a) = (a+b,0).(x,a)⋄(x+b,a)=(a+b,0).
So in particular S(x,a)=(a,0)S(x,a) = (a,0)S(x,a)=(a,0). For the remaining products (x,a)⋄(y,b)(x,a) \diamond (y,b)(x,a)⋄(y,b) with a,b,0a,b,0a,b,0 distinct, these should be set to (z,c)(z,c)(z,c) for some ccc distinct from a,b,0a,b,0a,b,0 subject to the rule
(x,a)⋄(y,b)=(z,c)  ⟹  (z,c)⋄(x,a)=(y+a,b).(x,a) \diamond (y,b) = (z,c) \implies (z,c) \diamond (x,a) = (y+a,b).(x,a)⋄(y,b)=(z,c)⟹(z,c)⋄(x,a)=(y+a,b).
This is a 6-periodic rule and can be filled out by the usual greedy algorithm.

It is not difficult to check that this obeys 1729. Unfortunately it also obeys 817: S2(x,a)=(0,0)S^2 (x,a) = (0,0)S2(x,a)=(0,0) and (x,a)⋄(0,0)=(x,a)(x,a) \diamond (0,0) = (x,a)(x,a)⋄(0,0)=(x,a) for all xxx. But perhaps we can use it as a base for a more sophisticated model.

If GGG is a boolean algebra, we can in fact choose the explicit form
(x,a)⋄(y,b)=(x+y+ab,a+b)(x,a) \diamond (y,b) = (x+y+ab, a+b)(x,a)⋄(y,b)=(x+y+ab,a+b)
which I think was also observed in the 1323 thread by @Bruno Le Floch .
If GGG is a Boolean algebra, this operation is commutative
So we have a lot to undo if we start there

I am thinking of using this as a model just for the squares. If ATPs do not rule out the possibility of the squares being commutative, closed under multiplication, and unital, then having a boolean model for the squares may be viable.

The squares would also obey S2=0S^2=0S2=0, so the general magma would obey S3=0S^3=0S3=0, but to my knowledge this has not been ruled out. (Also, 000 is only a unit within the squares; it is not required to be a unit in the larger magma, and probably we would have to abandon that property.)

Hmm, but I see from your previous post that one cannot have S3=0S^3=0S3=0 and 000 a unit for the squares, so indeed the boolean model cannot serve as a base model. (But it could perhaps be a base for a base...)

Hmm maybe you can clarify actually: if S3=0S^3= 0S3=0 and 000 is (say) a right unit for the squares, were you able to show that this implies 817 for all elements, or only for the squares? For if it is just the latter, we could still hope to use the boolean model as the base model to produce at least one contradiction to 817 (we don't need to contradict it everywhere, and I think in fact it automatically holds for squares in any case).
The boolean example is also an abelian group of exponent 4, and conversely addition on any abelian group of order 4 is a 1729 magma (funny how I never noticed that before).

Sorry, I was being brief (repeating arguments from earlier in the thread). The argument is as follows:

From 1729 one has LSxRxLxS2x=S2xL_{Sx} R_{x} L_x S^2 x = S^2 xLSx​Rx​Lx​S2x=S2x, which we can rearrange as LSxRxRS2xx=LSxRxxL_{Sx} R_x R_{S^2 x} x = L_{Sx} R_x xLSx​Rx​RS2x​x=LSx​Rx​x. Since LSxL_{Sx}LSx​ is invertible, we conclude RxRS2xx=RxxR_x R_{S^2 x} x = R_x xRx​RS2x​x=Rx​x. If xxx is a square x=Syx = Syx=Sy, then RxR_xRx​ is also invertible, so we conclude that 817 (RS2xx=xR_{S^2 x} x = xRS2x​x=x) holds for square numbers, or equivalently that Sy⋄S3y=SySy \diamond S^3 y = SySy⋄S3y=Sy for all yyy.

Here is an annoying obstruction:

Theorem. Suppose that a 1729 magma MMM is such that SMSMSM is finite and closed under multiplication. Then 817 holds.

So we will need an infinite base magma if one is to try to build the counterexample starting from the squares.

Proof. Let x∈Mx \in Mx∈M; our aim is to show that RS2xx=xR_{S^2 x} x = xRS2x​x=x. For a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM, we have LSaRaLa=1L_{Sa} R_a L_a = 1LSa​Ra​La​=1 by 1729, hence Ra−1=LaLSaR_a^{-1} = L_a L_{Sa}Ra−1​=La​LSa​. So, if we set ya:=LaLSax=Ra−1xy_a := L_a L_{Sa} x = R_a^{-1} xya​:=La​LSa​x=Ra−1​x, it suffices to show that yS2x=xy_{S^2 x} = xyS2x​=x.

For any a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM, we have
a=LSyaRyaLyaa=LSya(Raya⋄ya)=LSyaLxya.(1)a = L_{Sy_a} R_{y_a} L_{y_a} a = L_{Sy_a} (R_a y_a \diamond y_a) = L_{Sy_a} L_x y_a. \quad (1)a=LSya​​Rya​​Lya​​a=LSya​​(Ra​ya​⋄ya​)=LSya​​Lx​ya​.(1)
This already shows that the map a↦Lxyaa \mapsto L_x y_aa↦Lx​ya​ is injective from SMSMSM to SMSMSM (since by hypothesis LxL_xLx​ is injective and the bijection LSyaL_{Sy_a}LSya​​ preserves the finite set SMSMSM), hence is also a bijection. In particular there exists aaa with Lxya=SxL_x y_a = SxLx​ya​=Sx, hence ya=xy_a = xya​=x by injectivity of LxL_xLx​. Inserting this back into (1) we obtain a=S2xa = S^2 xa=S2x, hence yS2x=xy_{S^2 x} = xyS2x​=x as required. □\Box□

I think I was finally able to get a greedy construction to work to refute 1729 => 817. The details are en route to the blueprint at equational#866 (EDIT: now landed), but the ideas are as follows.

  • The carrier MMM will be the disjoint union M=SM⊎NM = SM \uplus NM=SM⊎N of a set SMSMSM of squares and a set NNN of non-squares.
  • For the squares SMSMSM, I took an infinite abelian group of exponent 4, which already obeys 1729. Because of previous obstructions, this was the simplest choice for SMSMSM that was available.
  • Next, we select the right multiplication operators Ra:N→NR_a: N\to NRa​:N→N for a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM. (It took me a while to realize that this was the component that had to be pinned down first, after fixing SMSMSM; I spent way too long trying to pin down LaL_aLa​ first.) Here I took the "free" option in which NNN is the free non-abelian group generated by ea,a∈SMe_a, a \in SMea​,a∈SM and RaR_aRa​ is left-multiplication by eae_aea​. So there are no relations between any of the RaR_aRa​.
  • Because of the 1729 identity L2aRaLa=1L_{2a} R_a L_a = 1L2a​Ra​La​=1 for a∈SMa \in SMa∈SM, we can write all the left-multiplication operators in terms of L0L_0L0​: indeed after some algebra one finds that La=eaL0e2a−1L_a = e_a L_0 e_{2a}^{-1}La​=ea​L0​e2a−1​ (where by abuse of notation eae_aea​ denotes left multiplication by eae_aea​).
  • One now has to select a map L0:N→NL_0: N \to NL0​:N→N, a squaring map S:N→SMS: N \to SMS:N→SM, and a multiplication operation ⋄′:N×N→SM\diamond': N \times N \to SM⋄′:N×N→SM obeying a certain number of technical axioms. It turns out that these axioms can be simultaneously satisfied by greedily selecting for L0,S,⋄′L_0, S, \diamond'L0​,S,⋄′ together (I had previously tried to select each separately, but they were coupled together too annoyingly to do so).

There are two technical issues that complicate this greedy analysis beyond that of previous constructions. The first is that the 1729 identity L0R0L0=1L_0 R_0 L_0 = 1L0​R0​L0​=1 implies that L02=e0−1L_0^2 = e_0^{-1}L02​=e0−1​. As a consequence, every time one greedily selects L0x=yL_0 x = yL0​x=y, one is forced to also select an infinite number of additional identities L0e0nx=e0nyL_0 e_0^n x = e_0^n yL0​e0n​x=e0n​y and L0e0ny=e0n−1xL_0 e_0^n y = e_0^{n-1} xL0​e0n​y=e0n−1​x. But this is a relatively orderly injection of additional identities, and while annoying, does not cause major difficulties.

More tricky is dealing with the implication
y⋄′x=z  ⟹  z⋄′y=LSy−1x y \diamond' x = z \implies z \diamond' y = L_{Sy}^{-1} xy⋄′x=z⟹z⋄′y=LSy−1​x
that is a rephrasing of 1729, and which means that every time one fills in one entry of the multiplication table, another one also must be entered. In previous constructions there was a periodicity that let one terminate this iteration after a finite number of steps (six, in fact); but now that LSyL_{Sy}LSy​ is constructed in a complicated fashion, and SSS itself was also being constructed concurrently with the other data for the magma, I did not see a way to enforce this periodicity. Instead, I had to introduce a new category to the greedy construction, that of a "pending identity" such as z⋄′y=LSy−1xz \diamond' y = L_{Sy}^{-1} xz⋄′y=LSy−1​x, which we want to be true, but cannot yet implement because SySySy is undefined. So each time a new entry of the multiplication table is defined, one often has to place an identity such as z⋄′y=LSy−1xz \diamond' y = L_{Sy}^{-1} xz⋄′y=LSy−1​x on the "pending" queue, and later when SySySy is defined, any relevant pending identities on the queue then have to be incorporated into the multiplication table (which often then causes further pending identities to go on the queue). It's a bit convoluted, but I did not see a better way to achieve this.

Certainly simpler constructions are always welcome! In particular they may be easier to formalize. I opened equational#869 to formalize the above argument, but if a simpler construction comes along it would make sense to formalize that instead.

Oh, fair enough. I meant to say a model where SSS was not surjective, and the iterates M,SM,S2M,…M, SM, S^2 M, \dotsM,SM,S2M,… didn't stabilize until at least the third power S3MS^3 MS3M. Though for the particular greedy construction I used, this wouldn't have been an obviously superior base model anyway, the point was it was hard to sustain genuinely non-surjective squaring over more than two iterations.

So you're now "mathematician-finished" but my instinct is not to celebrate until you're "lean-finished", because there may still be a twist in the story :-) Although it might be tedious to formalise the 80(?) or so "conjectures" we all know from experience that people can make mistakes... This is the "perspiration" after the "inspiration" in the old saying.

Congratulations to all, by the way! It's definitely a great milestone in the project.
